The Learning Lens: IV
“It’s easy for pupils to turn a classroom into a
side show, ” says Paul Guptill. He is recalling his
days as a teacher in Atlanta. “Many kids just
wait for any opportunity to alter the mood of a
serious lesson. I had to be careful about bringing
demonstration objects into the classroom. The
more common the object —an egg, let’s say—the
more it seemed to arouse giggling and wisecracks.
There’s nothing wrong with humor in the class¬
room, but when it gets out of hand, it’s at the
expense of learning.”
Now a television teacher, Guptill can drive a
small car into Atlanta’s educational-television
studio for a junior-high-school science lesson on
the conversion of fuel to power. “It takes time to
position the car and adjust the lighting so that
the camera can move around under the hood to
show the various parts,” he points out, “but none
of this time is wasted in the ten classrooms receiv¬
ing the lesson. By classtime, everything is set up.
I use the car as effortlessly as I would a test tube. ”
Jim Barfield, a colleague of Guptill who teaches
health on television, almost seems to be present
in the twenty-two classrooms his course reaches.
In a lesson on the blood and circulatory system
one day, Barfield pricked his finger under the
closeup lens of the camera. Several students
gasped. The next moment the screen showed a
photomicrograph of blood cells magnified thou¬
sands of times. Though physically removed from
